results.title: Madame Bovary [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Marin Karmitz, FR3 Films, C E D Productions and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: A young woman from a farm near Roen in France marries her local physician. A glimpse of high society living is experienced by Emma when they are invited to a ball. She cherishes this evening, remembering it as the best time of her life. The memory fades quickly however, and reality doesn’t match her high expectations of living. Growing tired of her inattentive husband and her burdensome child, she tries to push her drab life aside, looking elsewhere for love, excitement and a risque liaison. Secretly she carries out her double life, her debt increasing to keep her high living alive. She gives her all, but in return she’s not given enough. Cast includes Isabelle Huppert, Jean-Francois Balmer, Christophe Malavoy and Jean Yanne. Based on the well known novel by Gustave Flaubert.

results.title: Chuck & Buck
results.creator_credit: Miguel Arteta, Matthew Greenfield and Flan de Coco Film
results.brief_description: Chuck (Chris Weitz) and Buck (Mike White) were best friends as boys, but with the passing of time, Chuck has ended up a successful record executive in Los Angeles, while Buck has remained at home looking after his invalid mother. When the two of them meet at Buck’s mother’s funeral, Buck decides to follow his old friend to LA. But Chuck, now engaged and a professional, has little time for the nostalgic games that Buck wants to play. In order to win his old friend back, Buck stages a play at the theatre across the road from Chuck’s work. But the play - honest and fantastical, an adult fairytale - has far from the desired effect. Miguel Arteta’s film begins as an initially finely comic study of Buck, an innocent, unworldy man trapped in the fantasies of childhood. But increasingly, as his stalking of Chuck becomes obsessive and malignant, a darker tone appears in this film. Childhood games are revealed to be far from innocent: Buck wants to return to the playfulness of their sexual exploration when they were adolescent boys; but Chuck is fearful of the unresolved tensions and consequences of this early experimentation. Both Buck’s relentless refusal to be an adult, and Chuck’s equally fervent denial of his childhood sexuality lead to potentially dangerous consequences for both themselves and those around them. “Chuck and Buck” suggests it is only through the translating of his obsessions and fears into theatre, into drama and art, that Buck can find a way to release himself from the legacy of his childhood. For all its menace, “Chuck and Buck” allows the possibility not only for tolerance but an understanding to emerge between the old friends; an understanding not predicated on either false nostalgia or on denying the eroticism of friendship. The film also features some light-hearted affectionate satire about actors, auditions and the theatre world and features an excellent support performance by Lupe Ontiveros. Paul Weitz plays Chuck’s theatrical alter-ego. The film was shot on digital video format.

results.title: The Big circus
results.creator_credit: Joseph Newman, Irwin Allen and Allied Artists Pictures
results.brief_description: Victor Mature plays circus owner, Hank Whirling, an autocratic boss whose business is under threat of closure from changes to the entertainment industry and a saboteur whose work threatens lives as well as business. After borrowing heavily to keep the circus afloat Whirling is burdened with the presence of bank officer Randy Sherman and publicist Helen Harrison. Moving with the times is not one of Whirling’s strong points and he takes exception to having a female press agent. In a bid to boost dwindling sales Whirling reluctantly agrees to allow Zack Colino, his top aerialist, to perform a media attention grabbing feat - crossing Niagara Falls on a tight rope. Humour, comedy and colour pervade the film that constitutes good-natured family fun, as well as consisting of some stunning stunts. Originally filmed in cinemascope, “The Big circus” features a star cast including Vincent Price, Peter Lorre and Red Buttons. This film was to be one of Mature’s last leading men roles. Producer Allen Irwin, also co-wrote the screenplay with some-time Hitchcock collaborator Charles Bennet.

results.title: Jeremiah Johnson
results.creator_credit: Sydney Pollack, Joe Wizan and Sanford Productions
results.brief_description: Jeremiah Johnson is a film about life in the American mountains in the era of colonisation, and the people who sought to eek out an existence amidst nature, turning their back on civilisation. In this film Robert Redford stars as the titular protagonist who faces the perils of the unconquered West, learning the harsh ways and realities of surviving as a trapper in the bucolic terrain of North America in the 1850s. Once ensconced in the wild Johnson befriends fellow mountaineers, marries a Native American woman and adopts a mute son, (the survivor of a massacre), whilst settling into family life. Johnson finds himself increasingly at odds with his original pacifist intentions and as a result of a series of incidents, is driven to murderous encounters with the native Indians. Shot in Utah the film looks spectacular and addresses issues such as the significance of the land to Native American Indians as well as depicting the settlers’ endeavours to create a life in a savage physical environment. “Jeremiah Johnson” is a revisionist Western that along with “McCabe and Mrs Miller” (Altman, 1971) presents the pioneer life as a brutal and compromising struggle of humankind against nature and each other.

results.title: Arthur
results.creator_credit: Steve Gordon, Robert Greenhut and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Arthur Bach is a lonely and depressed alcoholic millionaire whose constant boozing and womanising mask profound unhappiness. His father and grandmother disapprove of his slovenly ways and have arranged for him to marry a suitably upper-class bore whom Arthur despises but complies when he is threatened with disinheritance. Arthur is forced to choose between wealth and love when he meets Linda Marolla (Liza Minnelli) and is drawn to her working class charm and sincerity. The screenplay is littered with witty one-liners mainly delivered by Dudley Moore, preceding gales of (his own) laughter. Although this habit occasionally grates it also reveals Arthur’s deep ridden angst about the emptiness of his moneyed existence. “Arthur” was an enormous hit at the box office and John Gielgud won an Academy award for his acerbic performance as Arthur’s confidant and butler. The binary conflicts between tradition and freedom, affluence and contentment, youth and age are reminiscent of the screwball comedies of the 1940s.

results.title: Pecker
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Polar Entertainment and Fine Line Features
results.brief_description: Written and directed by John Waters (Pink Flamingos, Hairspray, Serial Mom), ‘Pecker’ is an offbeat comedy set in Baltimore, Waters’ hometown. Pecker (Edward Furlong) is a happy-go-lucky 18 year old who likes nothing better than to take candid photographs of his eccentric family and friends, as well as unusual aspects of his environment. Pecker’s family consist of: Mom (Mary Kay Place) who spends her days dispensing fashion tips to the homeless; sister Tina (Martha Plimpton) who spruiks at a local gay strip bar; grandmother, (Jean Schertler) who receives religious messages from her Holy statue of Mary; and six year old sister Chrissy who is suffering from an eating disorder. Shelly (Christina Ricci) is Pecker’s girlfriend who runs a laundromat and encourages his artistic endeavours. At an exhibition of his work, Pecker is “discovered” by Rorey (Lili Taylor), a New York art dealer who promises him fame and fortune. Pecker’s notoriety brings public ridicule to those nearest and dearest to him and threatens the integrity of his art. Also starring Mink Stole, Bess Armstrong, Brendan Sexton III, with a cameo from photographer Cindy Sherman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Polar Entertainment and Fine Line Features

results.title: Daisies = Sedmikrasky [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Vera Chytilova, Ladislav Fikar, Bohumil Smida, Ceskoslovensky Filmexport and Filmove Studio Barrandov
results.brief_description: A modern fable in a stylised setting; the void within the two interchangeable heroines, Marie I and II, bursts forth as a destructive impulse, directed at an indifferent world, in the form of a series of happenings built around particular themes (death, consumption, acting, destruction of meaning). The apparent stylisation in performance, cinematography, sets and music is best understood as subversive of “socialist realism” which, prior to the “New Wave”, had been obligatory in post-war Czech (and East European) cinema. The film was banned for a year and condemned as Dadaist and Brechtian, “at absolute variance with the Marxist-Leninist mission in the arts” as an “official” critic put it. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: The Living end
results.creator_credit: Gregg Araki, Jim Stark, Marcus Hu, Jon Gerrans and Desperate Pictures
results.brief_description: On its release in the early 1990s, “The Living end” became one of the key films of the New Queer Cinema movement. Refuting both the conservatism of contemporary Hollywood and the increasingly bourgeois codes of “positive stereotyping” found in much of gay and lesbian cinema, Gregg Araki’s film celebrates and explores the sexual outlaws at the margins of Western gay life. Luke is a gay prostitute who lives on the streets. Jon is a sensitive movie critic who lives a comfortable, sterile life. The one thing they share in common is that they are both HIV+ and when they fall for each other they set about on a murderous road trip, killing anyone who gets in their way: macho homophobes, up-tight dykes, bitchy queens. Unlike films such as “Longtime companion” which attempted to homogenise and de-radicalise the experience of living with AIDS, “The Living end” shocked many viewers by placing two unapologetic survivors, whose anger and hatred is not muted, at the centre of its narrative. Araki’s low-budget aesthetic, influenced by equal measures of love for both punk music and the cinema of the French Nouvelle Vague, allowed him to create a truly dynamic, rough but wickedly subversive comedy road movie. Its humour, and its emotional vitality, remain undiluted.

results.title: Ski bums
results.creator_credit: John Zaritsky, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Ski bums: Crucial Mike’s definition - “being able to participate in a rich man’s sport without the financial means to do it”. This is a fascinating documentary which explores the lives of ten “ski bums” in Whistler, British Columbia, where 2.2 million international tourists visit annually and also where 10,000 ski bums live permanently. It is a choice of lifestyle, of extreme skiing and snowboarding, pushing the limits, of living for the moment and not worrying about what tomorrow may bring. It is also a question of survival and just how resourceful a ski bum has to be to pursue their magnificent obsession. Obtaining free passes, skis, clothing, even food sometimes, becomes part of the daily routine. Most have some form of casual or part-time work, but finding accommodation can be quite challenging. The film combines anecdotal stories, past and present, by Crucial Mike, Punchy, Johnny Thrash, Luddy, Cupcake, Stray Doggy and others with spectacular action footage of them skiing or snowboarding the breathtakingly rugged snowcapped mountains. With some great cinematography and music backing, Oscar winning director, John Zaritsky (Just another missing kid, 1982) has produced a refreshingly honest and upfront look at these devotees of the mountains. WARNING: SOME SCENES CONTAIN NUDITY, DRUG USE AND COARSE LANGUAGE.

results.title: Daughters of darkness = The Promise of red lips = The Red lips = Le Rouge aux levres
results.creator_credit: Harry Kumel, Paul Collet, Henry Lange, Maya Films and Showking Films
results.brief_description: In the lost space of an opulent Ostend hotel, eerily deserted in the off season, a young but hardly innocent couple on their honeymoon encounter the apparently ageless, sunlight-fearing, lesbian Countess Bathory. Kumel imaginatively balances the erotic malaise and violence of vampire folklore and a European (specifically Belgian) surrealist tradition with thirties Hollywood camp and comic strip tableaux. Perverse sexuality is located in a setting of decadent highlife which seems to immobilise the “victims”. Originally titled “La Rogue aux Levres” (Lips of Blood). Cast includes John Karlen, Delphine Seyrig, Danielle Ouimet and Andrea Rau.
